awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Function and Mechanism of Male Relationships In A Primate System
awd_abstract_narration:
Models of social relationships help to explain how and why social groups form, are maintained, and vary across primate species. These models typically focus on the number of males present in a social group and whether males are cooperative or competitive with each other. This project investigates the social behavior, demography, hormones, and genealogy of a wild primate species to understand the causes and consequences of male social relationships. The project will support conservation efforts by contributing valuable knowledge about an endangered primate in a poorly understood habitat and exemplifying to local residents the economic value of conservation. The research will support a new generation of scientists and conservation professionals via employment and training opportunities. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in data collection and analysis, gaining hands-on research experience in the US and abroad, building their research toolkits, and honing their critical thinking skills. Additionally, the project will increase diversity in biological anthropology by creating mentoring opportunities for minority and first generation undergraduates. Notably, by including a high school teacher in the research, the project will improve K-12 scientific curriculum development.

Recent data from a greater diversity of species has led researchers to question aspects of standard primate behavior models. Although models of male social relationships have sought to incorporate the social diversity that is present among males, these models continue to struggle to explain why numerous primate populations exhibit both single-male and multi-male social groups, and to predict when these variable grouping patterns occur. Moreover, while male influences are incorporated into models of female social relationships, models of male social relationships often treat females as inert resources and rarely account for female influences. Verreaux's sifaka in Madagascar provides an excellent opportunity to investigate explanations of male association and bonding because the species is renowned for both the variable presence of multi-male groups and female dominance over males. This project will examine behavioral, demographic, genetic, health, hormone, and body size data from multiple social groups over multiple years using the latest analytical tools to test new and existing hypotheses, and to inform and develop a model of sifaka societies that accounts for dynamic long-term patterns. It will explore multiple new suggestions for how current models can be modified, including (1) a more expansive and nuanced model that moves beyond a simple cooperation-competition dichotomy, (2) a role for females in influencing male association patterns and social relationships, and (3) a shift from viewing the number of males in a group as stable for a species to a new emphasis on variable and dynamic grouping patterns.

por.por_cntn:
Male-male relationships have been thought to be either competitive or cooperative and to be independent of female influence. We explored the hypothesis that males can be more complex and that their relationships with other males can range from resistant to tolerant to bonded. By using the latest genetic, endocrine, and analytical tools to quantitatively assess social relationships in a primate that defies easy classification and has proven enigmatic for previous models, our research allowed us to address fundamental questions about male social bonds. We combined newly collected and long-term behavioral, demographic, ecological, genetic, morphological, and hormone data, including 23,000 observation hours on 111 individuals between 2007 and 2019, and found that males are not very resistant to other males but are rather tolerant and even potentially bonded. However, our analysis of urinary oxytocin levels did not find evidence of physiological bonding among males. Because our study species, Verreuax’s sifaka (Propithecus verreauxi), exhibits multiple types of social groups, we also explored the hypothesis that multimale groups with only a few males function like single-male groups that just happen to have additional male residents. Our results were consistent with this hypothesis. Thus male-male relationships can be quite friendly and cooperative and fall along the tolerant to bonded side of the continuum. Despite exhibiting behaviors suggestive of male friendships, male relationships in multimale groups seems to be more opportunistic rather than tightly bonded.

Our results demonstrate the importance of using long-term data to answer questions about social relationships: many of the behaviors indicating potential bonds were evident only when looking at behavioral patterns over multiple years. Perhaps in the absence of physiological bonding, relationships can appear to be limited and competitive. However, when males live together for several years, evidence of stronger, more positive relationships can become apparent. In humans, close friends do not have to interact frequently in order to be important relationships or to be connected. Perhaps the same is true in nonhumans as well.

By using natural variation in sifaka grouping patterns, we tested central hypotheses about primate association patterns, competition, and social bonding. Our research highlights that the current understanding of male-male relationships is limited. By studying a species that exhibits (1) extensive variation in social grouping patterns and (2) a female-biased power society, we have been able to demonstrate the need for a paradigm shift. Current models of primate societies do not reflect the true complexity seen in the wild and ignore the ways in which females influence how males interact with each other. We are in the process of using the results from our study of one primate species to create a new, more comprehensive model of male-male relationships.

To date, the project has amassed the largest comprehensive dataset on this endangered primate species. It has trained multiple undergraduate and graduate students in the US, multiple graduate students in Madagascar, and a US high school biology teacher. It has resulted in multiple master’s theses and undergraduate honor’s theses, which have been presented at university and national conferences.

Our results demonstrate the importance of using long-term data to answer questions about social relationships: many of the behaviors indicating potential bonds were evident only when looking at behavioral patterns over multiple years. Perhaps in the absence of physiological bonding, relationships can appear to be limited and competitive. However, when males live together for several years, evidence of stronger, more positive relationships can become apparent. In humans, close friends do not have to interact frequently in order to be important relationships or to be connected. Perhaps the same is true in nonhumans as well.

Our research highlights that the current understanding of male-male relationships is limited. By studying a species that exhibits (1) a lot of variation in social grouping patterns and (2) a female-biased power society, we have been able to demonstrate the need for a paradigm shift. Current models of primate societies do not reflect the true complexity seen in the wild and ignore the ways in which females influence how males interact with each other. We are in the process of using the results from our study of one primate species to create a new, more comprehensive model of male-male relationships.
